title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 10
author: Various
snippet: "All being prepared, I bade adieu to your father, and embarked, in thedress of a Dutch skipper, on board of a vessel bound for Dysart,principally loaded with old iron, for the nailers of Pathhead.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 10
author: Various
snippet: "All being prepared, I bade adieu to your father, and embarked, in thedress of a Dutch skipper, on board of a vessel bound for Dysart,principally loaded with old iron, for the nailers of Pathhead.

title: The Heart of Mid-Lothian, Volume 2
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: His confession was said to have beento the following purpose: That he was one of twelve young men belongingto the village of Pathhead, whose animosity against Porteous, on accountof the execution of Wilson, was so extreme, that they resolved to executevengeance on him with their own hands, rather than he should escapepunishment.

title: The heart of Midlothian;
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: His confession was said to have been to the following purpose:—  That he was one of twelve young men belonging to llie vihage of Pathhead, whose animosity against Porteous, on account of the execution of TVilson, was so extreme that they resolved to execute vengeance on him with their own hands rather than he should escape punishment.

title: The heart of Midlothian;
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Among these, a fellow called Andrew Wilson, originally a baker in the village of Pathhead, was particularly obnoxious to the revenue officers.

title: Travels in the United States of America, in the years 1806& 1807, and 1809, 1810, & 1811;
author: Melish, John
snippet: From Pathhead, I travelled 16 miles to Cupar, through a variegated country, abounding in hill and dale, woods and small rivulets.
